title: Projectile motion - v0 for sphere on carbon paper

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A group of students is studying the two-dimensional motion of a sphere as it moves through the air. They have a spring-loaded launcher, which always launches the sphere with the same unknown speed <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. The students wish to determine <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> experimentally. To do this, they have access only to the items shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Besides the sphere and the launcher, the items are a <math alttext="60" overflow="scroll"><mn>60</mn></math>-centimeter-tall stand on which the launcher can be mounted horizontally and moved vertically to different heights, a meterstick, several sheets of plain paper, and several sheets of carbon paper. Whenever the sphere bounces off of the carbon paper, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, the carbon paper produces a visible mark on the sheet of plain paper that is under the carbon paper. (a) Describe an experimental procedure that uses the available items and would allow the students to determine the speed <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> at which the launcher launches the sphere. Including steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

frqParts.text: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A group of students is studying the two-dimensional motion of a sphere as it moves through the air. They have a spring-loaded launcher, which always launches the sphere with the same unknown speed <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. The students wish to determine <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> experimentally. To do this, they have access only to the items shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Besides the sphere and the launcher, the items are a <math alttext="60" overflow="scroll"><mn>60</mn></math>-centimeter-tall stand on which the launcher can be mounted horizontally and moved vertically to different heights, a meterstick, several sheets of plain paper, and several sheets of carbon paper. Whenever the sphere bounces off of the carbon paper, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, the carbon paper produces a visible mark on the sheet of plain paper that is under the carbon paper. (a) Describe an experimental procedure that uses the available items and would allow the students to determine the speed <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> at which the launcher launches the sphere. Including steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) The students are required to use a linear graph to determine the value of <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>.i. Identify two quantities that when graphed, will produce a straight line that could be used to determine <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>.
ii. Describe how the properties of the graph described in part (b)(i) can be used to determine <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>.

Later, the students analyze their data and determine that <math alttext="v sub 0 equals 4.1 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>4.1</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext></math>. Using the same launcher as in part (a) the students set up the experiment shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>. They disagree on the formula relating the horizontal distance <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math> that the sphere travels to the angle <math alttext="theta sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></math> above the horizontal it is launched from. Students <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> make the following claims.Student <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>: “I found this formula for <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math> on the Internet: <math alttext="D equals, the fraction with numerator v sub 0, end sub, squared, and denominator g, end fraction, times the sine of 2 theta sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mi>g</mi></mfrac><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>L</mi></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>.”Student <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>: “I think there is an error in that formula. I would expect <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math> to be proportional to <math alttext="the sine of theta sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>L</mi></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>, not <math alttext="the sine of 2 theta sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>L</mi></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>.”To determine who is correct, they write the following mathematical model: <math alttext="D equals, the fraction with numerator v sub 0, end sub, squared, and denominator g, end fraction, times the sine of n theta sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mi>g</mi></mfrac><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>n</mi><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>L</mi></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>, where <math alttext="n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>n</mi></math> is a positive constant and may or may not be an integer. The students wish to determine <math alttext="n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>n</mi></math> experimentally.Using the set-up shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, the students measure values of <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math> for different launch angles <math alttext="theta sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></math>, producing the data shown in the following table.<math alttext="theta sub L, end sub, in degrees" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>L</mi></msub><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>deg.</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></math><math alttext="D in meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>m</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></math><math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math><math alttext="0.335" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.335</mn></math><math alttext="10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn></math><math alttext="0.690" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.690</mn></math><math alttext="18" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>18</mn></math><math alttext="1.070" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.070</mn></math><math alttext="24" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>24</mn></math><math alttext="1.320" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.320</mn></math><math alttext="30" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>30</mn></math><math alttext="1.520" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.520</mn></math>(c)i. Identify what quantities could be graphed to yield a straight line that could be used to calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>n</mi></math>.Horizontal axis: __________ Vertical axis: __________Use the remaining columns in the table, as needed, to record any quantities indicated that are not already provided in the table. Label each column and include units.
ii. On the grid in Figure <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>, plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i). Clearly scale and label all axes, including units.
iii. Draw a straight line that best represents the data.

(d) Using the line drawn in part (c)(ii) and the launch speed <math alttext="v sub 0 equals 4.1 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>4.1</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext></math>, calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>n</mi></math>.

topic.text: 1.5: Motion in Two or Three Dimensions

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
